headline.main: Changes Requested In Ads for Youths

docs.abstract: Sens Mike DeWine and Christopher J Dodd say they will monitor extent to which alcohol advertising reaches young people and might hold hearings; survey of 19 radio markets by Center of Alcohol Marketing and Youth at Georgetown University shows beer and distilled spirits in 2001 and 2002 reached more young people than people ages 21 and over; reports listeners ages 12 to 20 heard 8 percent more advertising for beer and ale, 11.6 percent more for flavored malt alcoholic beverages and 14.5 percent more for distilled spirits compared with listerners of legal drinking age; Beer Institute president Jeff Becker says study interpreted data in questionable ways, adding that parents influence young people about drinking far more than advertising; activists join organization Commercial Alert to begin campaign to reduce childhood obesity by seeking bans on marketing and unhealthy snacks and beverages in schools; agenda sent to state legislators and health and education officials calls for ending practices like exclusive marketing deals between school districts and soft drink companies; endorsers include Center for Science in the Public Interest, Eagle Forum and Walter Willett, chairman at Harvard School of Public Health (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Activists are pressing for change on two youth-related issues, one involving alcohol advertising on the radio and the other involving marketing of snack foods in schools. Radio advertising for beer and distilled spirits in 2001 and 2002 reached more young people than people ages 21 and over, according to a survey of 19 markets released by the Center on Alcohol Marketing and Youth at Georgetown University in Washington. Compared with listeners of legal drinking age, the survey reported, listeners ages 12 to 20 heard 8 percent more advertising for beer and ale, 11.6 percent more for flavored malt alcoholic beverages and 14.5 percent more for distilled spirits.

headline.main: Obesity Drug Trial Produces Disappointing Weight Loss

docs.abstract: Shares of Regeneron Pharmaceuticals loses more than half their value after company reports its obesity drug Axokine produced only small weight loss in its first large-scale clinical trial (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Shares of Regeneron Pharmaceuticals lost more than half their value yesterday after the company reported that its obesity drug produced only a small weight loss in its first large-scale clinical trial. The effectiveness of the drug, Axokine, was inhibited by an unexpected problem -- two-thirds of the patients developed antibodies that attacked the drug itself, as if it were a germ, and neutralized it.

headline.main: Aliens Inside Us: A (Mostly Friendly) Bacterial Nation

docs.abstract: Dr Jeffrey I Gordon, Washington University in St Louis microbiologist, coins term bacterial nation to describe system of 500 to 1,000 types of microbes living inside our bodies; research into genomes of individual microbes and their evolution within our bodies could provide clue to drug-resistance; Gordon holds that bacterial sets should be grouped within species and thought of as single microbiome, suggesting bacteria works collectively within human bodies; drawing, photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: In the movie ''Alien,'' the creature of the title grows toothy and impatient inside John Hurt, finally bursting through his stomach in a fit of extreme and bloody pique, looking something like an albino salamander with fangs. It promptly scuttles off to become even more obnoxious. Leave it to the movies to exploit, with an unabashed lack of subtlety and taste, the nagging fear that there is something awful inside us. The fear is not without foundation. Peach trees and watermelon vines will not grow there, but parasites, worms and cysts will do fine. The list of potential co-inhabitants is long and gruesome. Any medical student knows that there is no need to fret about what lurks under the bed when you can lose sleep thinking about what lies within.
